trial_identification.studytitle: Can blood levels of Endothelin-1 predict liver function after liver resection?
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A study to determine whether serum levels of Endothelin-1 have any prognostic utility in predicting liver function post liver resection

conditions.healthcondition: post operative liver function and serum level of endothelin 1 and tumor necrosis factor alpha

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other diseases of the mouth, teeth, oesophagus, digestive system including liver and colon

interventions.interventions: Prospective study, post operative liver functional test and serum level of endothelin 1 and TNF are measured preoperatively an post operative day 1, 2 ,5

primaryOutcome.outcome: was to determine whether ET-1 levels has any prognostic utility in predicting PLF. Inflammatory response measured with serum level of tumor necrosis factor
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Serial post-operative serum ET-1 levels and TNF are measured preoperativelly and post operative day 1,2 and 5

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Department of Surgery, Hepatobiliary Unit, Scientific Institute San Raffaele

fundingsource.fundingname: Department of Surgery, Hepatobiliary Unit, Scientific Institute San Raffaele

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Postoperative liver failure (PLF) remains a relatively frequent and life-threatening complication after liver resection. Recent studies have demonstrated that besides the residual liver volume, damage of the microcirculation secondary to increased portal blood flow is a main determinant of PLF. Endothelin-1 (ET-1) is a multimodular mediator produced primarily by sinusoidal endothelial cells and is known to play a key role in the regulation of hepatic microcirculation and ischemia reperfusion injury. The aim of this study was to determine whether ET-1 levels has any prognostic utility in predicting PLF.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Oral presentation at International hepatobiliary surgery congress, july 1-5, 2012, Paris, France. The paper will be submitted at british journal of surgery
